Award.AwardTitle: Properties of Atomic-Scale Flow Defects in Metallic Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This project seeks to explore fundamental properties of the defects that accommodate flow in metallic glasses below the glass transition temperature, a necessary step toward fully explaining and predicting macroscopic deformation behaviors. Plastic deformation of metallic glasses is accommodated by thermally activated shear of atomic clusters, known as shear transformation zones (STZs), which are also responsible for anelasticity. Research results will include details of non-Arrhenian behaviors, guide future atomistic simulations and provide realistic input into mesoscopic simulations for practical applications. The effect of structural relaxation state, i.e., of processing, on STZ properties will be determined. To cover a wide range of time constants, quasi-static and dynamic anelastic relaxation measurements will be conducted using bend stress relaxation, nanoindenter cantilever bending and tensile measurements in a dynamic mechanical analyzer. Data will be analyzed numerically within the framework of a standard linear solid model developed by the PI. By exploring the size-density distribution of potential STZs as a function of processing history, proposed predictions for the potential role of the free volume, or a different structural variable, will be tested. Temperature-dependent measurements will provide direct information on size-resolved activation barriers. Further explorations will address the collective behavior of STZs and the effect of sub-yield, local, irreversible atomic displacements on STZ properties. In addition to new scientific knowledge, the work will provide opportunities for alloy design and will enhance graduate and undergraduate education. It will help inspire high-school students to pursue a career in science.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The freezing of a molten metal can produce a metallic glass. The strength and elasticity of metallic glasses make them attractive for applications in medical and other mechanical devices, as well as sporting goods. However, they exhibit limited ductility and toughness. Understanding the atomic-scale rearrangements associated with permanent deformation in these materials is a scientific challenge, but it is crucial to developing metallic glasses with improved ductility. In contrast to crystalline materials, in which the position of every atom is known, atomic positions in glasses are far less well understood. Thus, the nature of atomic rearrangements is a subject of active research. A recently developed method of characterizing shear transformation zones (STZs), small atomic clusters that undergo permanent shear as a result of deformation in a metallic glass, is used in this research. Analysis of time-dependent shape recovery reveals distinct signatures of STZs, resolved by the number of atoms they comprise. Critical experiments will be performed to explain previous experimental observations. The expected results include realistic input into simulations of macroscopic behavior, benefitting future development of ductile alloys. Increased understanding will be sought for the role of slow, reversible, deformation to benefit both manufacturing and the interpretation of experiments. The proposed work will promote the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, who will learn materials fundamentals, develop abilities to plan and conduct experiments and modeling and learn to communicate their results. The PI and graduate students will participate in high-school visits in under-resourced parts of the state of Michigan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Metallic glasses (MGs) are metal alloys in which the disordered structure of the liquid is frozen. Unlike in the vast majority of metallic materials, the atoms in a metallic glass are not arranged on a regular, crystalline, lattice. MGs have been used in transformer cores and magnetic sensors and transducers, and more recently in structural applications. They are good spring materials, as they are stiff and can be strained reversibly to a large degree without inducing permanent deformation. However, most metallic glasses are not ductile, and fail catastrophically when strained. For crystalline metals, the atomic-scale defects that form and move to accommodate deformation are well known, and can be imaged with modern electron microscopes. Because of the disordered structure of the MG, the atomic-scale details of its deformation are understood to a far lesser degree. The purpose of the project was to gain an understanding of the atomic rearrangements that accommodate deformation in order to develop the ability to design tough metallic glasses.

Based on simulations in bubble arrays, it has been proposed that metallic glass deformation is accommodated by near-spherical clusters of atoms, termed shear transformation zones (STZs). These flip into a distorted structure, while their surrounding matrix deforms elastically. For small stress, these “flips” are slow – the larger the cluster, the lower the flip rate. The basic experiment conducted was to bend samples to a well-defined curvature for about three weeks, then monitor the recovery of the original shape for times ranging from less than 1 second to more than one year. From the strain vs. time curve, we resolved distinct processes with different rates. Using results from the theory of shear transformation zones, one can identify a discrete number of atoms with each such process. 

Our analysis method has allowed us to interpret experimental data from the literature to an unprecedented quantitative degree. Our experiments, in combination with the analysis, have allowed us to explain artifacts in previously-used approximate methods. We have set the stage for understanding how MG ductility can be improved. We find that fast STZs, whose prominence in some La-based alloys has been attributed to ductility, are based on the smaller constituent atoms. We have characterized the effect of structural relaxation and the associated densification on the properties of shear transformation zones: their number decreases with structural relaxation, and for some alloys, they also slow down. 

When the strain relaxes with a single rate, its evolution can be described with a single exponent.  Many in the field use a phenomenological expression, the so-called “stretched exponent,” to describe the relaxation of a system that evolves with multiple rates. Deviation of the strain relaxation curve from the stretched exponent is frequently interpreted in the literature as proof that more than one relaxation mechanism operates.  However, since the stretched exponent does not reflect a physical mechanism, we have argued against such an interpretation. Moreover, we showed that use of the stretched exponent leads to inconsistent results. For the example of an Al-based MG we studied, we showed that the entire relaxation behavior can be described in terms of a simple STZ model, even though a stretched exponent analysis suggests two separate mechanisms.

Broader impacts

Two Ph.D. students have been trained in carrying out research that includes both experiment and computation/modeling. One has received his Ph.D. The second student is on track to completing her Ph.D. In addition, a Latino undergraduate student has contributed significantly to the research and is coauthor of a published paper.
